body:
#Starting to think it is simply the large stack frames -- perhaps with extra debugging stuff in debug mode, or simply less stuff optimised out -- versus Windows's 1 MB default stack size.

I looked at RSP when I had the stack trace open in the debugger.  Some individual calls result in very large RSP changes.  (I don't know if there's an automated way to check this for every line of the stack trace.)

~~~
__chkstk()
... another 10 or so calls before the stack overflow, several with quite big stack frames ...
0x00000052374bcad0 commands::impl$2::spawn::closure$0                      (38 kB jump)
0x00000052374c60f0 entity_command::impl$0::apply
0x00000052374c6140 command_handling::impl$3::with_entity::closure$0        (38 kB jump)
0x00000052374cf7e0 command::impl$0::apply
0x00000052374cf820 command_handling::impl$0::handle_error::closure$0        (38 kB jump;)
0x00000052374d8e90 command::impl$0::apply
0x00000052374d8ec0 command_queue::impl$4::push::closure$0                   (115 kB jump)
0x00000052374f5030 FnOnce::call_once
0x00000052374f5090 command_queue::impl$4::apply_or_drop_queued::closure$0
0x00000052374f50d0 unwind_safe::impl$25::call_once
0x00000052374f5130 catch_unwind::do_call
<unknown>
0x00000052374f51f0 std::panicking::catch_unwind
0x00000052374f51f0 std::panic::catch_unwind
0x00000052374f5290 RawCommandQueue::apply_or_drop_queued
...
~~~

Take the 115 kB frame in `command_queue::impl$4::push::closure$0`.  That's the `CommandMeta { consume_command_and_get_size }` closure in `command_queue.rs:162`.  I don't know if there's anything in there that could be changed to use less stack.

The next ones are in `command_handling.rs:45`, `command_handling.rs:128`, and `commands/mod.rs:386`.  Not sure what that 38 kB used each time is.

## Update

The Command, and the spawned `impl Bundle`, are 38 kB as serialised data in the command queue.  So I'm guessing several of these functions end up storing it on the stack, and the big ones store it multiple times.  Maybe in some cases we can explicitly avoid that.

rename.to: Stack overflow with large-ish Bundle spawn

body:
Changed the title to reflect that it's not specific to feathers.

Windows's small stack combined with dev-mode optimisation levels has exposed the problem but it's a lurking issue for other environments, once peoples' Bundles get big enough.

Most of the time Bundles will be small enough that it doesn't matter, and I guess there may be an unwanted performance cost to *always* allocating the Bundle to spawn.  If the `children!` macro put its results into a `Box` or `Vec` that would alleviate the problem (and fixes the feathers example) but there's always the possibility someone wants to spawn enough big components in one entity that it still crashes.

Don't know how explicit we want the spawn API to be -- should there be separate functions/macros for keeping parts off the stack?

> Most of the time Bundles will be small enough that it doesn't matter

While that may be true most of the time, it's not at all uncommon in UI work to spawn panels that have complex nested hierarchies. Particularly in editors. The feathers demo isn't particularly excessive compared to some UIs I have seen.

issue.body:
# Objective
`ArchetypeAfterBundleInsert` caches information about changes to an entity's archetype after a bundle has been inserted. It's currently stored in a `SparseArray`, so it's stack size can have a significant impact on the amount memory used to store ECS metadata ,even if an edge does not exist between two archetypes.

## Solution
Use boxed slices instead to shrink the stack size of `ArchetypeAfterBundleInsert` by 40 bytes. Went ahead and also did the same with `BundleInfo` (16 bytes per registered `Bundle`)

## Testing
Existing unit tests and miri have been run.

body:
Checking Rust's [`std::thread`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/thread/index.html#stack-size) documentation, it states that the default when spinning up new threads on al Tier 1 platforms (Windows included) is 2MiB, but the stack size on the main thread is not determined by Rust.

This rules out just upping the default stack size Bevy uses in its thread pool, albeit that is probably still a good idea with efforts like Forte utilizing stack allocation more aggressively.

In the intermediate term, it may be best to split up the Feathers example to piecemeal spawn/insert the components necessary. Long term, we may want to find a way for spawning/insertions with additional effects to avoid recursion where we can avoid it.

body: Hmm I don't love the implication that we need to rewrite "standard" code to avoid stack overflows. The example rewrite makes things much uglier, and the idea that there is a tipping point here for "normal" code feels fundamentally broken to me, to the point that I would consider holding back the release to fix it.
Well, I'm guessing the quickest thing you can reduce the stack size is to put the contents of `children![]` on the heap.

We could provide an explicit way for users to box things when it becomes a problem.  I had a go with this:   https://github.com/ejrh/bevy/commit/02206e09d2b4c831a1792e379a0fea072a1c1d38

I personally do not like it.
 1. Users don't necessarily know when a bundle/compilation/environment will one day cross the magic stack size threshold.
 2. It's ugly (maybe this can be improved).

Boxing `children!` might be better but there is still the possibility of single-entity bundles growing to enormous size without children.

On the whole I would be in favour of the Bundle API putting things in Boxes automatically or even by default.  I know this has performance implications.

This might actually be an ideal use case for in-place insertion/initialization (#20420).

The Rust project has also proposed lang-ifying [pin-init](https://github.com/Rust-for-Linux/pin-init), which might be usable now with a major UX hit.

As an alternative (or in addition to that), we could have world-owned bundle scratch space, which we write Components to, roughly command-style. That would allows an API that inserts components one-by-one without knowledge of the final bundle. Less efficient than an API calculates the bundle / archetype first, but also more dynamic.

While that might be good for the longer term, I think that in the short term boxing the `Related::spawn()` tuple is likely to have fewer knock-on effects. We've never had problems with stack overflows spawning bundles before this, and it's specifically the deep nesting of the children hierarchy that is blowing up the size so much.

I worry that if we fundamentally change the way that bundles are spawned this late in the game, we'll either end up leaking some of that change into the user-level API, or we'll notice a difference in performance. While boxing the children tuple will also have some performance impact, it's going to be much less: for a tree with an average fan-out factor of N, the number of `Children` components is generally going to be (number_of_nodes / N).

The CPU cost of additional heap allocations is only paid during spawning, a process which is already heap-intensive, so it may get lost in the wash. Maybe. If that's a concern, perhaps something like `bumpalo` could mitigate this.
